Before leaving Singapore, Raffles did leave some plans and policies that were important for the development of the settlement.
Before leaving Singapore, Raffles did leave some plans and policies that were important for the development of the settlement.

Raffles conceived a town plan to remodel Singapore into a modern city. The plan consisted of separate areas for different ethnic groups and provision of other facilities such as roads, schools and lands for government buildings. In October 1822, a Town Plan Committee was formed by Raffles to oversee the project.

Although Farquhar was said to be the one who stayed in Singapore to support its development, Raffles provided the planning, the strategizing, and was the one to select Singapore as another British base, giving early Singapore support of the British. If William Farquhar was to be proclaimed the founder because he did the "grunt work", shouldn't the supervisor of a construction site get the most commission, instead of the contractor? And besides, Raffles left Singapore under the orders of his superiors and he did not leave of free will

argues Raffles established educational i.description: argues Raffles established educational institutions; specifically, the text mentions Raffles' role in creating schools and institutions as a significant contribution to Singapore's development. texts:
Schooling
Raffles established the Singapore Institution ( Now known as Raffles Institution ) which completed its construction on the year 1837.

Raffles conceived a town plan to remodel Singapore into a modern city. The plan consisted of separate areas for different ethnic groups and provision of other facilities such as roads, schools and lands for government buildings. In October 1822, a Town Plan Committee was formed by Raffles to oversee the project.

Although Farquhar was said to be the one who stayed in Singapore to support its development, Raffles provided the planning, the strategizing, and was the one to select Singapore as another British base, giving early Singapore support of the British. If William Farquhar was to be proclaimed the founder because he did the "grunt work", shouldn't the supervisor of a construction site get the most commission, instead of the contractor? And besides, Raffles left Singapore under the orders of his superiors and he did not leave of free will

texts: Raffles founded Singapore and Farquhar was just a subordinate for Raffles. So it was normal that Raffles gave he duty of turning Singapore into a successful city and left the city to Farquhar to handle.

Raffles was the person who signed a treaty with the Temenggong and also the Sultan Hussien, and not William Farquhar. I agree that William Farquhar was the one that remained in Singapore to keep it running and also developed it further, but Raffles was the one who gave him the position because he had to leave and return to Bencoolen, also, he was the one who laid out the foundation of Singapore's Development, so he should be considered a founder.
It was Raffles that led the expedition in order to find a new trading port. Farquhar only tagged along with Raffles. So even if Farquhar did not come Raffles would have still founded Singapore.

argues that Farquhar followed Raffles' i.description: argues that Farquhar followed Raffles' instructions and plans; specifically, the text states that Farquhar was merely a subordinate who carried out Raffles' vision for Singapore. For example, 'Raffles gave he duty of turning Singapore into a successful city and left the city to Farquhar to handle.'
texts: Raffles founded Singapore and Farquhar was just a subordinate for Raffles. So it was normal that Raffles gave he duty of turning Singapore into a successful city and left the city to Farquhar to handle.
It was Raffles who signed the treaty with the Sultan Hussein,not Farquhar. Farquhar was just Raffles subordinate.

Even though it is true that Raffles did not work closely with the population to develop Singapore, he provided plans, ideas and was going to put them in action by himself when his superiors ordered him to Bencoolen. Hence it was common sense for Raffles to leave his subordinate to finish his ideas

Although Farquhar was said to be the one who stayed in Singapore to support its development, Raffles provided the planning, the strategizing, and was the one to select Singapore as another British base, giving early Singapore support of the British. If William Farquhar was to be proclaimed the founder because he did the "grunt work", shouldn't the supervisor of a construction site get the most commission, instead of the contractor? And besides, Raffles left Singapore under the orders of his superiors and he did not leave of free will

It was undoubtedly Raffles' ambition and vision which led him to search for another British base in the Straits of Malacca, and to select Singapore as the best location to achieve British economic and strategic objectives in the region. Without Raffles, it is likely that Singapore would have remained a sparsely inhabited island, on the margins of the Dutch colonial empire in the East Indies.

It was undoubtedly Raffles' ambition and vision which led him to search for another British base in the Straits of Malacca, and to select Singapore as the best location to achieve British economic and strategic objectives in the region. mentions Raffles leaving Singapore due t.description: mentions Raffles leaving Singapore due to orders; specifically, the text claims that Raffles left Singapore not by choice, but because of orders from his superiors. For example, 'Raffles had to leave Singapore as he was ordered to Bencoolen, leaving Farquhar to execute his plans.'
texts: Even though it is true that Raffles did not work closely with the population to develop Singapore, he provided plans, ideas and was going to put them in action by himself when his superiors ordered him to Bencoolen. Hence it was common sense for Raffles to leave his subordinate to finish his ideas

Although Farquhar was said to be the one who stayed in Singapore to support its development, Raffles provided the planning, the strategizing, and was the one to select Singapore as another British base, giving early Singapore support of the British. If William Farquhar was to be proclaimed the founder because he did the "grunt work", shouldn't the supervisor of a construction site get the most commission, instead of the contractor? And besides, Raffles left Singapore under the orders of his superiors and he did not leave of free will

highlights raffles' international connec.description: highlights raffles' international connections; specifically, the text stresses the importance of raffles' network to help singapore thrive economically. for example, 'raffles used his connections to gain support for the transformation of singapore.'

credits raffles for singapore's social p.description: credits raffles for singapore's social principles; specifically, the text points out that raffles instilled values like multiculturalism and tolerance, essential to singapore's identity. for example, 'raffles advocated for a diverse and inclusive society in singapore from the start.'

addresses raffles' historical recognitio.description: addresses raffles' historical recognition; specifically, the text discusses raffles' established legacy as the founder of singapore. for example, 'monuments, museums, and other landmarks in singapore honor raffles as the city's true founder.'
texts: Raffles founded Singapore and Farquhar was just a subordinate for Raffles. So it was normal that Raffles gave he duty of turning Singapore into a successful city and left the city to Farquhar to handle.

It was undoubtedly Raffles' ambition and vision which led him to search for another British base in the Straits of Malacca, and to select Singapore as the best location to achieve British economic and strategic objectives in the region. Without Raffles, it is likely that Singapore would have remained a sparsely inhabited island, on the margins of the Dutch colonial empire in the East Indies.

discusses Raffles' other achievements; s.description: discusses Raffles' other achievements; specifically, the text highlights Raffles' accomplishments outside Singapore to demonstrate his capability as a founder. For example, 'Raffles also played a significant role in the establishment of British interests in the region, bolstering his claim as Singapore's founder.'

mentions the recognition and honors alre.description: mentions the recognition and honors already given to Raffles; specifically, the text notes existing statues, monuments, or institutions named after Raffles as evidence of his status as founder. For example, 'Raffles already has a number of honors, such as statues and the Raffles Hotel, which showcase his importance in Singapore's history.'

analyses the nature of Farquhar's role;.description: analyses the nature of Farquhar's role; specifically, the text delves into Farquhar's duties and responsibilities, showcasing his limited influence on Singapore's development. For example, 'As the Resident and Commandant, Farquhar was in charge of the settlement's administration, but he did not possess the authority to shape its founding vision.'

mentions the establishment of the Britis.description: mentions the establishment of the British trading post; specifically, the text refers to the agreement Raffles signed with the Sultan of Johor to use the southern part of Singapore as a trading post and settlement. For example, 'Raffles signed an agreement with the Sultan of Johor on behalf of the British East India Company on February 1819.'
